subNodes.conversationText: root
"Retreat! Retreat!"
[Continue.]
The magicianâ€™s command was unnecessary: everyone else had already fled. Embittered and enraged, blood trailing from her mouth, Mnesse vowed revenge.
[Continue.]
"Watch your step, witch -- both you and Zaurus."
"For now," she said, turning away.
[Continue.]
The magician glided into the woods, her feet a few inches above the forest floor.
[Continue.]
The body that she had kicked lay where the brigands left it. It was that of a middle-aged man, plump and dressed well. He had been beaten and stabbed multiple times.
"They're new to killing but quite earnest about it," <FirstName> mused.
The corpse had probably been picked clean, but it was possible the bandits had missed something.
<FirstName> checked.

The bandits had been less thorough than <FirstName> expected -- or perhaps <he/she>'d come upon them before they'd had a chance to search their prey. The man had no money, but he wore a silver ring. It was a wayfarer's ring, signifying the blessing of some tutelary spirit.
<FirstName> took it.

It was hard to get off. The man's fingers were fat and clammy. The young witch had to grab his wrist with one hand and pull hard with <his/her> other, and even then the ring didn't budge. The look of agony frozen on the corpse's face made <FirstName> fancy that <he/she> was hurting him.
<He/She> kept trying.
At last the ring came off. The young witch pocketed it.
[Continue.]

<He/She> had Knott roll the corpse into the woods. Meanwhile, the crow had become a little too curious. He had flitted around it while it was being moved. Now he was hopping up and down the body and poking at it with his beak.
<FirstName> left it alone.
<FirstName> left it alone.

<He/She> had Knott roll the corpse into the woods. Meanwhile, the crow had become a little too curious. He had flitted around it while it was being moved. Now he was hopping up and down the body and poking at it with his beak.
<FirstName> decided not to check.

<He/She> had Knott roll the corpse into the woods. Meanwhile, the crow had become a little too curious. He had flitted around it while it was being moved. Now he was hopping up and down the body and poking at it with his beak.
"Leave it alone, Pharaoh," <FirstName> said. "Let's go."
<FirstName> waited until the crow was done investigating.
The corpse was too new and unyielding for Pharaoh's beak. He flew back to the witch's shoulder.
[End.]
"Rotten scoundrels," <FirstName> muttered.
The corpse had probably been picked clean, but it was possible the bandits had missed something.
The young witch gave no more thought to the crime.
The corpse had probably been picked clean, but it was possible the bandits had missed something.
"I don't know who Zaurus is! I've never heard of him!" <FirstName> called after her.
She didn't respond.
<FirstName> watched her go in silience, catching <his/her> breath.
"You forced my hand."
"Forced? I didn't know witches could be forced to do anything," she said. Then she turned away.
[Continue.]
"We have no reason to fight," responded <FirstName>.
"Yes we do -- many. I bleed: That's a reason. You've wounded and scattered my band -- another reason. Revenge is a reason. And Zaurus is a reason." She turned away.
[Continue.]
The magician glided into the woods, her feet a few inches above the forest floor.
"I could kill you this instant. Don't force my hand."
Pharaoh croaked in agreement.
[Continue.]
"Forced? I didn't know witches could be forced to do anything," she said. Then she turned away.
[Continue.]
